facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 300 of 1961 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 300 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 13, 1957 of Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 19-D of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 13, 1957, of the Punjab High Court at Chandigarh, in Lettes Patent Appeal No. 19-D of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 5, 1963 by SHAH J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March 5. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-The Oriental Bank of Commerce Ltd. was

facts.text: Oriental Bank of Commerce Ltd. incorporated in February 1943 under Indian Companies Act, 1913.

anchor.surface_text: The Oriental Bank of Commerce Ltd. was incorporated in February 1943 under the Indian Companies Act, 1913. The Bank had its registered office at Delhi

facts.text: Bank had registered office at Delhi and branches in Lahore and other towns now in Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank had its registered office at Delhi and it opened branches in Lahore and in other towns which are number in Pakistan.

facts.text: Capital divided into 5,97,584 ordinary shares of Rs. 10 each and 24,200 B class shares of Re. 1 each.

anchor.surface_text: The capital of the Bank was divided into 5,97,584 ordinary shares of Rs. 10/- each, and 24,200 B class ordinary shares of Re. 1/- each.

facts.text: Paid-up capital as on December 31, 1946 was approximately Rs. 23 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: The paid., up capital of the Bank as on December 31, 1946 was approximately Rs. 23 lakhs On account of disturbances

facts.text: Bank lost substantial assets in West Pakistan due to disturbances after partition.

anchor.surface_text: On account of disturbances which followed in the wake of the setting up of the Dominions of India and Pakistan, the Bank lost a substantial part of its assets

facts.text: By 1950 accumulated losses amounted to Rs. 10,57,850.

anchor.surface_text: in the territory number called West Pakistan and was unable to recall its advances. By 1950 the accumulated losses of the Bank amounted to Rs. 10,57,850/-

facts.text: In December 1950, Directors made a call of Rs. 2/8 per share on ordinary shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1950, the Directors of the Bank made a call of Rs. 2/8- per share on its ordinary shareholders.

facts.text: Extraordinary General Meeting convened on November 29, 1951, special resolutions passed reducing capital.

anchor.surface_text: They also resolved to reduce the capital of the Bank and for that purpose an extraordinary General Meeting of the Bank was companyvened on November 29, 1951 and special resolutions were passed

facts.text: Reduction to Rs. 4,56,137 ordinary shares of Rs. 5 each and 24,200 B-class of annas 8 each by cancelling paid-up capital.

anchor.surface_text: reducing the issued and subscribed capital of the Bank to Rs. 4,56,137 ordinary shares of Rs. 5/- each and 24,200 B-class ordinary shares of annas 8 each. This reduction was to be effected by cancelling

facts.text: Displaced Persons Debts Adjustment Act, 70 of 1951 enacted before special resolution.

anchor.surface_text: Before the special resolution was passed the Parliament enacted the Displaced Persons  Debts Adjustment  Act, 70 of 1951.

facts.text: Application submitted to District Judge, Delhi (Company Judge) under ss. 55,56,57 Companies Act for reduction.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the resolution passed by the Bank at an extraordinary General Meeting on November 29, 1951 an application was submitted before the District judge, Delhi

facts.text: Application opposed by two shareholders claiming circumvention of Act 70 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: This application was opposed by two shareholders who companytended that the Bank was merely trying to circumvent the provisions of the Displaced Persons  Debts Adjustment  Act, 70 of 1951

facts.text: Company Judge allowed petition, confirmed resolution with surrender option for displaced persons under s19.

anchor.surface_text: The Company judge allowed the petition an companyfirmed the resolution reducing the share-capital on the terms and companyditions relating to surrender accepted by the Bank and directed that numberice be given under S. 61

facts.text: Respondent Harcharan Das Loomba holder since 1944 of 500 ordinary shares Rs.10 each, Rs.5 paid.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Harcharan Das Loomba was a holder, since 1944, of 500 ordinary shares of the face value of Rs. 10/- each on which Rs. 5/- were paid.

facts.text: Respondent was displaced person within Act 70 of 1951, undisputed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents claim that he is a displaced person within the meaning of s. 2  10  of the Displaced Persons  Debts Adjustment  Act, 70 of 1951 is number disputed.

facts.text: Respondent did not appear at hearing or avail surrender option.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was a displaced person within the meaning of Act 70 of 1951 but he-did number appear at the hearing of the petition for reduction of capital, number did he avail himself

facts.text: On January 7, 1954 respondent applied to Bank under s.19(2) to convert 500 shares to 250 fully paid-up.

anchor.surface_text: On January 7, 1954 he applied to the Bank under s. 19  2  of Act 70 of 1951 to companyvert his holding of 500 ordinary shares into 250 fully aid up shares.

facts.text: Bank declined by letter January 16, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: By its letter dated January 16, 1954 the Bank declined to carry out theon.

facts.text: Respondent petitioned Tribunal under s.19(4) for conversion order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then petitioned theTribunal under s. 19  4  of the Displaced Persons Debts Adjustment  Act for an order directing the Bank to companyvert 500 partly paid-.

facts.text: Bank resisted claiming Company Judge order conclusive and binding, failed to avail option.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was resisted by the Bank, inter alia, on the grounds that the order of the Company judge sanctioning reduction of capital and granting facility for surrender their holding to shareholders

facts.text: Bank claimed good grounds for refusal: no assets, need for calls and new capital.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank also submitted that the right companyferred by s. 19 4  of Act 70 of 1951 was number absolute and that there were good grounds for number companyplying with the requisition under s. 19  2 ,

facts.text: Tribunal held Bank scheme to deprive displaced shareholders, affirmed by Punjab HC Khosla J and Div Bench.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Tribunal losses suffered by the Bank and doubtful debts had been accumulating for a long time, but the Bank resorted to the scheme of capital reduction after Act 70 of 1951

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave, the Bank has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Tribunal ordered conversion, confirmed by Supreme Court as no good cause shown.

anchor.surface_text: The order directing the Bank to companyvert the shares of the respondent into fully paid-up shares must therefore be companyfirmed, because numbergood cause has been shown by the Bank
